lines.text: You know something, Wally? I'd rather do nothin' with you than somethin' with anybody else.
Do you really like me, Wally?
I guess so.
Do you like me a whole lot?
Look, don't get sloppy on me. I might just slug you one.
Gee, your kitchen always looks so clean.
Why, thank you, Eddie.
My mother says it looks as though you never do any work in here.
Wally, where are you going?
I'm going over to slug Eddie.
That's no way to talk, this is Sunday.
You're right, I'll wait 'til tomorrow and slug him in the cafeteria.
How'd the fishing go Beav?
Great Dad. We didn't catch any fish, but Larry and I saw a man slip on a wet rock and heard everything he said.
I'm going to change my clothes and finish painting those trash cans myself; the boys ran out on the job.
Well dear you can't blame them too much, they went over to see the big fire at the lumber yard.
Fire?
Yes, they couldn't resist it, and after all they are just boys.
Tom Corton's lumber yard?
Yes, it's been on the radio. Why, they've called out fire companies from all over.
Well it must be quite a fire.
Yes, it must be.
June, I wonder if you'd go out to the garage and put those brushes in some turpentine, I won't be too long. (Rushes out the back door.)
Once a boy always a boy.
How come Eddie's such a creepy guy?
He works at it.
Wally, if your dumb brother tags along, I'm gonna - oh, good afternoon, Mrs. Cleaver. I was just telling Wallace how pleasant it would be for Theodore to accompany us to the movies.
Beaver, you know what Larry was doing was wrong. You could have stopped him.
Gee, Dad, I have enough trouble keeping myself good without keeping all the other kids good.

[Mr. Foster is reading out the class grades]
Miss Rogers, A, Mr. Haskell, B+, Mr. Cleaver, A-, Mr. Rutherford, F.
An ?F?, Mr. Foster?
Yes, Mr. Rutherford. It's the lowest grade they allow me to give.
We can't just say we're going to be friends. We gotta have an agreement or something.
Okay.
I, Beaver Cleaver, swear to die for Larry Mondello and always stick up for him and never snitch on him and be his friend forever.
Not me! Your father doesn't like me.
Why would you say that?
On account of the way he looks at me when he opens the door. Sometimes I think he'd be happier to see Kruschev standing there.
Look Sam, if you can make the other guy feel like a goon first, then you don't feel like so much of a goon.
I don't get that.
Of course you don't. That's because you never went to kindergarten with a home permanent.
Have to keep a firm hand on boys nowadays, Ward. My Clarence answered me back the other day. I smacked him right in the mouth. None of this psychology for me.
Ah, June, Gilbert's always talking about his parents. Have you ever met them?
Oh, I see her at the supermarket every once in a while. She seems like a calm sensible person.
You can't really go by that. You might look the same way to her.
Did Dad hit ya?
No.
Did he yell at ya?
No.
Then why ya cryin'?
Sometimes things get so messed up, crying is the only thing you can do.

[Wally and Eddie's prank on Lumpy has backfired]
Clarence! Did you wrap this chain around the axle of your car and then try to drive off?
Gosh no, Daddy! Why would I do something like that?
It just seems like something you would do.
[Ward has opened the car door for June to enter]
Thank you dear. It's so sweet of you to be the thoughtful husband after all these years.
Your very welcome. Besides the neighbors might be watching.
Boy, Beaver, wait'll the guys find out you were hanging around with a girl. They'll really give you the business.
But gee, Wally, you hang around with girls and the guys don't give you the business.
Well, that's because I'm in high school. You can do a lot of stuff in high school without getting the business.
[repeated line]
Gee Wally, that's swell.
Ward, I'm very worried about the Beaver.
Are you giving me the business?
Where'd you hear all that jazz?
Dry up, Beaver.
Are you being a wise guy?

[Beaver thinks he isn't going to graduate from 8th grade]
Hey, that's tough, kid. Let me think. Maybe I can help you figure a way out of this.
Listen, Beav. At this point, I don't think you want to be taking advice from Eddie.
Are you kidding? I've been in an out of every kind of trouble there is in school.
You wanna' mess around later?
I can't, I'm grounded.
How come?
My father caught me eating pie in bed.
Sometimes I wish I had stayed single and raised silver foxes.
Boy, I sure wish there was somebody in the family for me to yell at.
That's your tough luck.
Eddie seems to know a lot about the law.
Yeah, he told his father, in three years he's going over the wall.
[at a backyard funeral]
These here are Beaver's pigeons, which he named after his two teachers, which the cat ate, so he buried them.
Eddie, would you care to stay for dinner? We're having roast beef.
No thank you, Mrs. Cleaver. I really must be getting home. We're having squab this evening.
I could use my own money, the twenty-five dollars I got in the bank.
I thought you were saving that to go to college.
Larry says he never heard of a college you could go to for twenty-five dollars.

[to Lumpy]
Lumpy Dumpy Rat Rat.
Gee Dad, how come you know so much about buying cars?
Well, Wally, as unbelievable as it may seem they did have cars in my younger days.
Used cars?
Wally, believe it or not, I was your age once.
[to Beaver]
What a dumb thing to do. I bet you wouldn't have done anything like this if Mom and Dad were here.
Dear, do you think all parents have this much trouble?
No, just parents with children.
It's that friend of Beaver's. You know, the one who always talks like he was just frightened by something.
Whitey Whitney?
That's it.
[Ward has told the boys how he used to walk to school as a kid]
[to Beaver]
Yeah, every year the distance gets longer and the snow gets deeper.
Let's face it, June, Wally and Eddie have been friends for four or five years now - nothing's ever really happed.
But Eddie has that look about him that makes you think something's always about to happen.

I would like to be a bear, gay and happy free from care / That's the life like no other, climbing trees with my mother / Though they call me beast of rage, I've never put things in a cage / Or set a trap since time's begun, or shot a human with a gun.
[Richard has lost the three dollars his mother gave him to have the families laundry washed]
I wish I was young enough to cry.
Yeah, now the only place you can cry is in the movies where it's dark.
If I had my choice between a three pound bass and a girl, I'd take the three pound bass.
Violet Rutherford drinks gutter water.

[Ward wants to see Beaver in the den]
Is Dad mad?
Yeah, but Mom's in there.
Beaver punched me in the stomach, right where I almost had my operation.
Things would be all right if my daughter could just find a husband. Then we'd always have a man around to give it to Larry when his father's out of town.
Hey, guys, like my new vest? I think it brings out the Peter Lawford in me.
[Ward has arrived home from work and is reading the mail in the living room, unbeknownst to June and Wally who have just come down the stairs]

Now Wally, I want you to go in the living room and pick up those orange peels that you left on the coffee table. If your father comes home and sees them he'll be in a terrible mood all through dinner.
Yeah, I don't want him hollerin' at me again.
[June sees Ward in the living room, who has overheard their exchange]

[sheepishly]
Hello Dear. I was upstairs, I didn't know you were home.
Oh yes, the monster has returned to his cave.
[June has prepared a lovely dinner of barbecued pork ribs]
Well, you boys are very quiet tonight. What are you thinking about?
I was just thinkin' what I'd do if I was a pig eatin' peoples ribs.
Beaver, please.
[Entry in Beaver's diary]
Went to school. Ate lunch. Saw dead cat. Came home.
Hi Dad. I didn't do anything.
Why do you say that?
Well, I don't know, but, uh, you have that look on your face like somebody did something.
I wouldn't wanna do anything to hurt God. He's got enough trouble with the Russians and all.
[Beaver and Larry are having a picnic at Friends Lake]
Hey Larry, how come food tastes better when your eatin' it outside?
I don't know. Maybe 'cause if you drop something, nobody's gonna' holler at ya' for gettin' dirt dirty.
[repeated line]
Oh, fine!
[Eddie's mother is concerned about him taking a summer job on an Alaskan fishing boat]
It's such a rough life and Edward's so sensitive.
Sensitive? He's about as sensitive as an armadillo.
Just watch what your sayin' Beaver or I'm liable to clop you one.
Cross my heart and hope to spit.
[Fred has walked to the Cleaver's to catch a ride to work with Ward]
I hate to mention it, but this neighborhood's getting a little on the rough side.
Oh?
Yes. Coming down the block just now, a kid yelled, "Hey skinhead" at me.
That was a great jungle movie, huh Beav?
Yeah, but there was too much kissin' and not enough apes.
[Wally's in love]
What's the matter with you, Wally?
Whatta' you mean what's the matter with me?
You look like that time you ate all those rotten eclairs you found in the trash behind the supermarket.
A man never gets so old, that he forgets how it was being a little boy.
Hey Wally, how come Dad's taking us out to dinner and a show?
I don't know; I think it's on account of togetherness; like you read about in the magazines. You know, it's supposed to make us a happy family and all that kind of junk.
Couldn't we be a happy family just eatin' in the kitchen?
Na, that's no good. Ya' gotta' go out and show people your a happy family.
Mr. Whitney?
Who, me?
Yes. I spoke to you yesterday about making faces at Miss Hensler, didn't I?
I'm not making faces Mr. Willet. I just can't help laughing when I look at her.

[to Wally]
Your father gave me a funny look when I came in... like I'm a teenage werewolf or something.
[Wally and the Beaver are having a talk about girls]
I guess girls stop makin' ya' sick just about the same time baths stop makin' ya' sick.
How will I know when it happens to me?
Well, one of these days when you're checkin' your own ears for dirt, girls will start lookin' good to ya'.
[Wally is cutting the Beaver's hair after he "losted" his haircut money]
Are ya' finished yet, Wally?
Well, I don't know if I'm finished, but I think I better stop.
[Ward is sharing the story of Pandora's Box with the boys]
According to Greek Mythology, she's responsible for all of Man's troubles.
She must be like Judy Hensler.
Beaver... you got crumbs in the butter again. Boy, if there's one thing I can't stand, it's crumbs in the butter.
Sorry Wally. That must have happened when it fell on the floor.
There's nothin' sadder than seein' old people try to be happy.
[repeated line]
Beaver, your mother and I are very disappointed in you.

[Repeated line]
Daddy!

[to Wally when they are ready to fight at school]
Lucky for you the bell rang!

[Beaver and Gilbert see an older girl that Wally is sweet on enter a tavern]
You know what she is, Beav? She's what you call a woman of the world.
